info.game_comments:
1998 College Championship quarterfinal game 2.
  From Zellerbach Auditorium at the University of California-Berkeley.

(1, 1).clue: Lots of Lutherans live there; its parliament is the Folketing; its royal library is in Copenhagen

(2, 1).clue: Our internet address, also known as this type of name, is Jeopardy.com

(3, 1).clue: As head coach, he puts the Indiana Pacers through their paces

(4, 1).clue: Unlucky Cuban fisherman catches huge fish; sharks eat it

(5, 1).clue: His 1982 album "Thriller" spawned the No. 1 hits "Beat It" & "Billie Jean"

(6, 1).clue: The common name for the robe you wear with a cap when you graduate

(1, 2).clue: Some locals eat a fruit called tuna; it's the home base of the Lima Times; llamas live there

(2, 2).clue: Baseball term used for a visit to a web page; Jeopardy.com gets 14.7 million per week

(3, 2).clue: The last man she divorced was Larry Fortensky

(4, 2).clue: Greek sailor wanders around for 10 years & finally finds his way home; his wife isn't angry

(5, 2).clue: Andre Young is better known as this influential "physician" of rap

(6, 2).clue: This term for the "A" or "B" you make in a course is from the Latin for "degree"

(1, 3).clue: Goat is served as an entree; Spanish Town is the former capital; it's home to the Reggae Sunfest

(2, 3).clue: Jeopardy.com has this hypertext connection to a page where you can play "Jeopardy!" online

(3, 3).clue: Plumbing-supply wholesaler Moe Gorelick is the father of this bestselling saxophonist

(4, 3).clue: Bad day for a wedding: Jane's fiancee is already married, and his wife is nuts!

(5, 3).clue: Noted singer & tour organizer heard here

(6, 3).clue: From the Greek for "letter folded double", it's the document presented to a graduate

(1, 4).clue: It's a republic; it's in Africa; it has a tusk material in its name

(2, 4).clue: Netscape makes this type of client software used to access & navigate web pages like Jeopardy.com

(3, 4).clue: Alisan Porter was "Curly Sue" in 1991 & this child star was "Curly Top" in 1935

(4, 4).clue: Socrates & pals hang around Cephalus' house talking about the ideal state...& talking...& talking

(5, 4).clue: Despite its name, this group seen here is better known for its music than its encounters with the police

(6, 4).clue: Add 3 letters to a synonym for "ailing" to get this word for a small campus hospital

(1, 5).clue: It grows a lot of barley; its national anthem is "Long Live The King"; it's ruled by the man seen here(King Hussein)

(2, 5).clue: Unsolicited junk e-mail is called this, the name of a Hormel canned meat

(3, 5).clue: Bart Simpson might phone this establishment & page "Ringing, first name Isabelle"

(4, 5).clue: Leopold makes breakfast, walks around Dublin all day; goes home; goes to bed

(5, 5).clue: In 1995 Montell Jordan had a No. 1 pop & R&B hit with "this"

(6, 5).clue: 3-letter term for the head of a British college or the head of a Mafia family

(1, 1).clue: Thomas Midgley, who put lead into gasoline, introduced this now banned refrigerant in 1930

(2, 1).clue: A golden age of Jewish culture began in the 10th C. under these people who ruled Spain

(3, 1).clue: Sarah Tueting & Cammi Granato were 2 of the heroines of this triumphant U.S. team

(4, 1).clue: The mallard is one of the most widespread wild species of this bird

(5, 1).clue: In "Scream", this actress seen here was the first to scream

(6, 1).clue: An abecedarian is a person who's learning this, a necessity for "Wheel of Fortune"

(1, 2).clue: In 1931, to produce this fiber, Wallace Carothers heated hexamethylene diamine & adipic acid

(2, 2).clue: Now a term for an urban minority area, this word originally referred to an area set aside for medieval Jews

(3, 2).clue: Chris Thorpe & Gordy Shear went horizontal to win the USA's first silver medal in this event

(4, 2).clue: The name of this talkative bird seen here can be spelled with or without an "H" at the end

(5, 2).clue: "I want my work to scare you to death", said this buff little actress & vampire slayer

(6, 2).clue: These socks with a diamond-shaped pattern are fit for a duke

(1, 3).clue: Studying "on the rocks" of northern Europe, Jean Louis Agassiz developed the idea of this "age"

(2, 3).clue: In 1994 a bomb killed 96 at a Jewish community center in this S. American city where Eichmann once lived

(3, 3).clue: Perhaps afraid of being shot by mistake, officials stopped this event due to fog & snow

(4, 3).clue: This genus of woodpecker includes the red-breasted & the yellow-bellied types

(5, 3).clue: This former movie "Batman" is a distant cousin of the poet who wrote "Trees"

(6, 3).clue: It's a place where bees are kept, though it sounds like a home for gorillas

(1, 4).clue: The "scope" of his career covers classifying galaxies by type & a constant on how fast they're receding

(2, 4).clue: Biblical Palestine was divided into Israel & this kingdom named for one of Jacob's sons

(3, 4).clue: Beaten out by Ilya Kulik, this Canadian left the building with a silver medal in figure skating

(4, 4).clue: The toulouse, a breed of this bird, is especially popular at Christmas

(5, 4).clue: He plays the snidely sarcastic Dennis on "Just Shoot Me" -- what a card!

(6, 4).clue: Your nose knows this adjective means shaped like an eagle's beak

(1, 5).clue: The story goes, when asked to determine if King Hieron's crown was pure gold, this man figured out how to do it

(2, 5).clue: The first congress of this movement met in 1897; its goal of Israeli statehood was achieved in 1948

(3, 5).clue: Cross-country skier Bjorn Daehlie of this country won 3 golds, making him the Winter Games all-time leader

(4, 5).clue: In falconry, the terms falcon & tercel traditionally apply to the female & male of this species

(5, 5).clue: This actor has won 2 Tonys for "Brighton Beach Memoirs" & for the show ("How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying") in which he sang the following

(6, 5).clue: In "Paradise Regained", Milton called this European capital the "Mother of arts and eloquence"

(0, 0).clue: In 1883 he wrote, "Your true pilot cares nothing about anything on Earth but the river"
